text:
PAX HEHMEYER: My
name is Pax Hehmeyer. I'm the director of
Academic Programs here at Stanford Online and the
Stanford Center for Professional

Development, joined
today by my colleague Jonathan Notman, who's
the senior director of Client Success and Engagement
at Stanford Online and SCPD.

So today, we will be
telling you a little bit about the credit-bearing
programs that

are available through
Stanford Online. We'll be going in
more detail there. Before we get started, I wanted
to go over a few logistics.

So first of all,
welcome everyone. Thanks again for
joining us this morning. We know your time
is really valuable,

and we appreciate that
you're spending some of it with us to learn more
about these programs. Second, as I said earlier, we
do want to hear your questions,

and we will get to as
many of them as we can. You should see a little
Q&A box in your interface. Feel free to type a
question in there.

We are joined-- Jon and I are joined by
several of our colleagues today who will answer
some of those questions

directly through chat. And then we will answer
some of the other ones in the course of
the presentation.

And then at the
end, we also have-- and throughout, we'll stop
occasionally to sort of look through the questions
and address any other

that we see are common. I'm going to go over a
little bit of the background, the high level about
Stanford Online

and the Stanford Center for
Professional Development. And then Jon will go
into some more details

about the
credit-bearing programs and the Non-Degree Option
and the part-time and online master's degrees.

And then again, we'll have some
time for questions throughout. So the first thing that I
wanted to share with you

is just the history
of the Stanford Center for Professional Development. We are actually nearing our 70th
anniversary or-- not SCPD per

se, but our programs are
nearing their 70th anniversary. We started-- a version
of started in 1954.

We are part of the
School of Engineering, and we started in the
School of Engineering. We started when Fred
Terman, who was then

the dean of Engineering,
electrical engineering professor, he established what
is called the Honors Cooperative

Program. And that is a
part-time-- then it was a part-time master's degree
for working professionals

to take Stanford classes
while they were working. Now, of course, then
it wasn't online. It wasn't even
really at a distance.

It was people who
were in the Bay Area and really pretty much
adjacent to Stanford's campus. That evolved over the years.

We moved from just totally kind
of being colocated with Stanford to an instructional television
network that would broadcast

to the Bay Area. And then it moved to
a satellite network that could go outside
of the Bay Area.

And then in the '90s, we moved-- we started moving online. And by '98, we had our
first fully online degree.

That was also in
electrical engineering. And since then, we
haven't looked back. And it's really been in
the last 15 years, where

we've moved almost
fully online, especially with the rise of a lot
of the new learning management systems, that
you're no longer mailing things

in to us. And that was true even
15 years ago if that's-- maybe that's surprising.

In terms of-- in terms of
what is offered here at SCPD, so we do have a broad
variety of offerings.

And this is kind of a visual
that shows you that range.

Jonathan and I will be talking
about the right-hand side of this range but I
wanted to briefly mention

that we do have a lot of
other learning experiences and learning resources
that are available outside of the credit-bearing programs.

So first of all, I'll
mention our free material that's not listed here,
but we have a lot of it.

If you haven't
already visited it, I would encourage you to go
to Google, the Stanford Online YouTube channel.

A significant
number of our course lectures and course materials
are available there.

And I will also say that
especially in computer science at Stanford, a lot
of the course website--

there are a lot of
public-facing course websites that include
syllabi, that include

problem sets, that include
past projects from students. So you're all here today
to do some research

to learn about these
programs at a broad level. If you find a course that you're
interested in that we offer, I would encourage you
to google that course

and to see if it has a
public-facing course website to see if we have
some of those lectures available on our YouTube
channel because that's

a really good place where
you can spend some time to learn more about what
that content looks like.

And that's going to answer your
questions about what you're going to cover in that far
better than anyone on our team

could because that's coming
directly from the teaching team. So I really encourage you as
you're thinking about some of these courses.

Even if the course you're
interested in isn't available, I'd encourage you to google
and look around at those things and see what free
materials are available.

That will help you
prepare, and it will really give you a good sense of what's
covered in those courses. So let me briefly
cover these red-- kind

of the red certificates. These are, perhaps
confusingly, called our professional programs. And what that means is
they're not credit-bearing.

All these programs are directed
at professional learners, meaning people who are
not full-time students and usually who are
working while studying.

So these professional
programs, these are again not credit-bearing. They are things
closer to something

like a MOOC, a
Massively Online Course. Often, they're self-paced. We do have some cohort courses. There's a lot of variety
in there in what we offer.

I know many of you have
mentioned that you joined us

last week for our
informational session on our artificial
intelligence programs. We have a lot of
professional programs

in artificial intelligence. And so that's another
opportunity that you have. Again, not credit-bearing but
a lot of different learning

experiences. So maybe you don't have the
time to do credit-bearing, but you might have the time to
do something that's self-paced.

So there's a whole breadth
of learning experiences that we offer at Stanford
Online and through the Center

for Professional Development. So what Jonathan and I, however,
will be focusing on today

is what we call the
Non-Degree Option. And these are your
opportunity as a professional to take a single
course at Stanford

or to pursue a
graduate certificate. As a Non-Degree
student, you won't be a fully matriculated
student, but you

will be a student at Stanford. You will have login rights. You will be attending and
taking the same classes that are happening on campus,
but you will only

be doing it at a class
at a time or pursuing a graduate certificate, which
is a WASC-accredited-- which

is an accredited
graduate certificate. And again, we'll go into a
lot more detail about these,

so I'm just giving you
the broad overview. Finally, the other thing
we will be discussing

are some of the degrees that
are available to students who want to pursue it on a
part-time basis and/or online

and specifically
master's degrees in the School of Engineering. So one thing to say
at the outset and we

will repeat it is these
are the same degrees that are happening on campus. There is one application. What we support is a status
within that degree, which

is to be a part-time student
with the option to do some of your coursework online. There are degrees that can
be completed fully online,

and we'll talk a little
bit more about that. But again, there's
just-- this is just the Stanford master's degrees.

You would apply to one
of the degrees that is supported through SCPD. And if you were to get in, you
could petition the department

to be a part-time
and/or online student. OK, I see a lot of good
questions coming in.

And maybe one to
address right away is for those master's degrees,
you are a fully matriculated student, right?

You are a fully matriculated
Stanford student. You have been admitted
into a degree program. And so you would be-- have
the option to be part-time,

but you could come in person. You could do it online. For the Non-Degree, those
are online programs. And again, I want to use
that to kind of segue

into what this
experience is like. So the first thing
to say is what

I'm going to describe as
kind of our typical class. We support about 60
classes a quarter.

And so there can be a lot of
variation in these classes. A lot of the kind of
details around the logistics

are set by the faculty
who are teaching the class unsurprisingly and not by us.

So what I'm going to describe
is the typical class experience. Again, there could
be some variations.

So as I mentioned
before, whether you are a Non-Degree student
pursuing credit-bearing classes

or a master's student,
the classes you are taking are the same classes that are
happening in person on campus.

And what we do is we schedule
them in one of our rooms, and we staff it with
course producers. And we record those
lectures as they're

happening in the classroom. You have the
opportunity to watch those lectures after they've
occurred or as a live stream.

In some cases, there's
two-way communication, the ability for you
to ask a question out loud during the session.

In most cases, there is not. And that's because these
are big lecture classes. And in most cases, the students
who are taking these programs

as an online student or a
part-time student are working, and they're not able to
join a lecture live during--

between 9:00 and 5:00
Pacific Time either because they're working or
they're in a different time zone.

And so these classes tend to
be larger lecture classes that do not require attendance
during those lecture sessions

but require to watch
those lectures. Office hours are available, and
they will have online office

hours that will again-- to what extent of all their
office hours will be online will vary a lot,
depending on the class.

But especially in the bigger
classes, a lot or all of them will have an online option. Faculty do generally
try to make those

available at different
times to accommodate people in different time
zones or working.

So it'll just
depend on the class, but in some cases in
the really big classes, you'll have kind of office
hours available almost all day

during the week, especially-- yeah. So there hopefully will be
one that's available to you

to join online. And if there weren't, you would
reach out to the teaching team or to us to see if there were
a way to make it possible.

The assignments that
you would be doing, these would also, for
the most part, be online.

There's one exception
exams, and I'll get to that. But you will be doing-- you're responsible
for all the same work

that's happening on campus. It is the same class. You are earning a Stanford
transcript and a grade for it,

so you're doing
all the same work. There will be usually
discussion forums. That's where a lot
of the communication

happens for these classes. Regardless of whether
you're online or on campus, that's where you post questions. TAs would answer
those questions.

Other students will
answer those questions. So those are very
active discussion forums for these classes.

Now I mentioned that the
assignments and most things are online. There is one exception,
which is right now exams.

If your class has
an in-person exam, you will need to
find a way to take it in person wherever you are.

You don't need to come to
Stanford's campus, obviously, but you will need to nominate
what we call an exam monitor.

So this is a person who will
be responsible for receiving the exam, printing it
out, and making sure

that you observe the time limits
and the rules around the exam like if you can use
a calculator or not

use a calculator,
those kinds of things. We have a lot more information. You can see in the interface
there's a link to our exams FAQ,

so I encourage you to go there
to dig into that in more detail. But in short, an exam monitor
is often your supervisor

at work or an HR
professional at your work, someone with a professional
relationship to you

who will be in the
office at the same time as you are when you need
to take those exams.

Because a lot of our
students these days are not going into the office
or not going into the office as frequently,
another way to do this

is to work with a
professional exam service. So a lot of universities
will have that. There will just be a
testing centers, in general,

are getting more
and more common. Libraries often have this. Again, local colleges or local
community colleges in your area.

So there are a lot
of options there for how to handle
the exam monitors. But again, that does--
that is something

you have to do in person. Now not all classes
will have exams, so not all classes
will require them.

But if there is
an in-person exam, that is something that
you will need to arrange. And you'll need to think about
that early on when you're

sort of planning your course. Is there someone at
work that will do this, or do I need to go
to a testing center?

We do have some
resources to help you find those testing centers.

It can be hard for us, of
course, if you're abroad, and we may not always know where
all the testing centers are

or ones that are
close to you, so. You'll probably do some
searching on your own.

You can also ask other students
at SCPD what they're using.

Finally, I'll mention how all
this is available is you do-- how you can access all these,
the learning management system,

the videos, the email, all--
you will get a Stanford email and login credentials
to Stanford systems

during the time that you are
actively enrolled in a course. And so that will allow you to--

that will allow you again
to log into the course to view everything, to
access the online library materials that are
available at Stanford,

and to use other services like
the Stanford Slack, the Stanford Zoom, those kinds of things. That will all be essential
to sort of supporting you

while you're studying here. And so those-- so it is--
again, I want to repeat.

This is the same-- these
are the same classes. They're happening on campus. And you are an online
student taking it

alongside those
on-campus students. And I like to say that that is
a challenge and an opportunity.

It's an opportunity
because we're not changi-- in a lot of programs,
it's like it's changed.

It's simplified. It's like, this is
exactly the same class. And that's the
opportunity that we're offering you is to take and do
and handle the same material

that is happening here. The challenge is, of
course, that there are on-campus students who can
turn to the student next to them

easily in the class
and ask a question. These are all, for the most
part, full-time students also who are in the classroom.

And you are a part-time student,
so there are unique challenges that you will face as an
online student in a class that

has both online and
in-person audiences. And so at that point,
I want to highlight

some of the things that are
important to think about when you're getting prepared
for these and something to think about whether
this is right for you

and if you do choose to enroll
in a course, how to prepare. So the first thing
to note is these

are intense classes, right? They are the actual
graduate-level engineering classes, so I would prepare. We say prepare for 15 to 25
hours of coursework per week.

It's like a part-time job. There's a lot of work
that's happening. You will have
deadlines every week,

so it's not a self-paced course. It follows a quarter system
which is 10 weeks long.

If you're used to a semester
or a different kind of system, they move fast.
The classes move fast. There's a lot of work involved.

When you do start a class, I
think the most important thing is to just as soon as you can,
that first day that the course

is open or the syllabus is
published, take a look at it, look at the key deadlines,
and get them on your calendar,

and think about how they work
with your work deadlines. So you're going to have to do
that kind of special scheduling.

On that note, you want to make
sure that your work is aware that you're doing this, that
your coworkers are aware,

and that your friends
and that your family-- I realize I should
add family here. Family is probably the
most important people

who should be aware
that you're doing this so that you have the support. They're aware that
you're undertaking essentially a part-time job.

And finally, I'll say there
are a lot of opportunities through us to help where you
can find some of that support.

And these are our online
orientation, so every quarter Jonathan and I hold
an online orientation.

We go over-- some
of the details, we'll go over today
and other logistics. And we also have
quarterly social mixers.

Some of those are in-person,
and some of those are online. And that allows you to
meet other students.

Both the orientation
and the mixers allow you to meet
other students who are doing this online program.

It's a really great way
to meet other people who are both taking your class
but also can provide you

the kind of tips and resources
that you find typically just in a classroom, being able
to turn next to someone.

This is kind of--
you can think of it-- these are your opportunity to
build that auditorium of people you can contact who are doing
the same thing you are and can

provide you those tips. So I see a lot of
questions are coming in. Jon, should we just move
on, or are there any

you want to address now before
we move into your section? JON NOTMAN: I think we can
answer some rather than kind

of bundle up at the end, so. I don't know if these have
been replied to in the chat,

but there's some questions
that I'll quickly run through and you can take some as well.

So I'm looking here. And there was a question
about, are certificate courses

self-paced? Professional certification
programs are self-paced, but the programs that
we're talking about right

now are credit-bearing courses. Those are not self-paced. They follow an academic quarter
structure or an academic quarter

system, not a semester system. And then there was
a question about,

can we pass from online
courses to master degree using the past courses?

We'll talk about
that in a minute. You can actually-- if you're
taking credit-bearing courses through the Non-Degree
program and you

apply to the
master's degree, you have the opportunity to use
some of the course credits

and courses that
you have previously completed if you
again apply and are

accepted into master's degree. There's a question here about
GRE and IELTS requirements.

There are some degree programs
that require GRE and IELTS. Some do not.

It varies. The Non-Degree program does not
require a GRE or an IELTS exam,

so you don't need those. But you need to research
whichever degree you're interested
in, and that might

be applicable to the degree
you're interested in. One of the other questions--

let me see here. There are some--
there's a question here. There are some master's degrees
that offer fully full-time that

are in large part credits. Can these be done
online before applying to the full-time degree?

Again, if you're interested in
a degree program, a Stanford degree program, you can complete
courses and course credits

in the Non-Degree program and
apply those in some cases. When you apply and are approved
and matriculated into a degree

program in the first
instance-- we're talking about the part-time master's degree--
you can start that program

in a part-time-- on part-time basis. But if you wish to transfer
to full-time, you can. You have the right to do that.

And you can actually transfer
from the full-time program back to the part-time
program if you wish. So those are all opportunities
that are available to you.

It's a very flexible program. Pax, do you see any
other questions? PAX HEHMEYER: Yeah, I'll maybe--

just two-- so the
first is just the being able to come on campus.

So these are-- so if
you're a master's student and you've been approved to
do it on a part-time basis

and take online coursework,
you're fully matriculated. You have access to the campus. You can get a-- if you're a local, you
can get a Stanford ID.

You are a matriculated student. You can come in
person for classes. You don't have to just
take the online classes.

If you are interested in the
Non-Degree option program-- well, again, we'll go more
detail about both of these--

then you are supposed
to be an online student. And that means you are expected
to watch the lectures online,

to do most of the
coursework online. You will not have
access, for instance,

to the Stanford library-- on-campus Stanford
library by virtue of being a Non-Degree student.

Now you can go for-- I think it's-- I forget
what the numbers are now, but I think it's $100. You can buy access to the
Stanford library in person

if you wanted to go in and
use the library in person. There is one exception with
approval, and that's for exams.

Yes, if you're a local. And the faculty approve. And that's the key thing. They don't always
approve it because there

are real capacity issues
with people coming in person. So if the faculty approve
it that you can sometimes

come in person to take
the exams on campus. And so that would be
the one exception there,

but you are expected to
be an online student. Now again, if you're
a local and you're working on a project with
matriculated students,

of course, you can
come and meet them, and maybe you're going
to meet at a coffee shop on campus or nearby.

That's normal. But you are expected to be doing
the lectures and things online.

The other thing I just-- and I
think, Jon, you mentioned this. But just to-- I didn't do a good job
of sort of describing

the relationship between the
Non-Degree and the master's program. And Jon will go over
this in more detail, but.

So I don't want to jump the gun,
but when you apply to the no-- you apply, you
submit an application

for the Non-Degree option
that we keep on file. And every time you want
to enroll in a course,

you submit an
enrollment request. We send the application to be
reviewed by the department. They'll review that and
your Stanford transcripts,

and they then will approve
you for the individual course or not approve you.

It's kind of a course level. If you take four
of those courses, three or four, depending on
it, you can earn a certificate.

We'll go into more detail. You do not need to
declare to pursue that certificate at the outset.

You can complete
those four courses. And as long as you've completed
it within a certain time frame, then you would let us
know, and we would give you

the certificate if
you've completed the requirements
for the certificate within the time frame.

The master's degree then
is a separate thing, right? You then apply-- you apply
to the master's degree

as a Non-Degree option could be
applied towards that master's degree if the
coursework is relevant. So there is a kind of a
stacking that goes on there.

And I just wanted
to go over that. We'll go over it again. So Jon, with that, I'm going
to hand it over to you. Sorry to jump the gun, but.

JON NOTMAN: No, no, it's OK. Just before we do that,
there are two key questions I don't want to lose focus
on because they are important

and I want our audience
today to understand.

One key question-- and this
is very, very key for me. Question was, are the courses,
the credit-bearing courses

that students can take online
through the Non-Degree program in lockstep with the courses
that are on Stanford campus?

They are exactly the same. They are the same ones. These are not different courses. These are not courses
put on by SCPD.

These are the same
courses that matriculated full-time students who
are on campus will take.

You will undertake
the same study. You will undertake the same
coursework, same exams.

Everything is identical. You will get the same
credits, et cetera.

So that's important to not
lose sight of that fact. And the other key question, I
think, is critical as well is--

somebody asked
about the challenge behind forming study groups. Now I'd like to get
Pax's opinion on this,

but my opinion is it
can be a challenge. However, with the assistance
of the course teaching team

and with the various kind of
discussion topic-based platforms that we have, it shouldn't be
too difficult to form a study

group. And if you do find
that challenging, please reach out to us or
the course teaching team,

and we'll be more than
happy to assist that. I understand it can
be a challenge based on if you're a working
professional and making

the commitment to the times that
you've agreed on for the study groups. But it is not impossible.

It just takes a little
bit of organization Pax, do you have any
thoughts on that? PAX HEHMEYER: Yeah. No, I agree with you.

It is certainly possible. And more than ever
it's possible. And so as Jon said,
what I would do

is I would join our
online orientation. That's done over Zoom, and
we encourage all the students

to join that to just
put their class their in and if they're comfortable,
where they're located.

And then we will
have those mixers. And then when you're
in the class itself, there's usually something like
a discussion forum or a Slack

space. And again, that's where
students will usually-- I think you need to be more
active on those than some

of the on-campus students
because the on -campus students are turning to the
people next to them. You see students posting on
those, hey, my name is Pax.
I'm in the Bay Area. I'm taking CS221.

I work as a-- none of this is true about me. I work as a programmer
at X company. Would love to get together with
anybody who's taking that class

and form a study group. And what you'll find-- I mean, we actually have some
funny stories of people who are taking these classes and find
out literally the person who's--

they're taking it
from Washington, DC, and the person who
lives two blocks away is taking the same course as
they are at the same time.

And they form a study group. And other times
you'll find students who may be who can find local
groups doing the same things.

Maybe it's a little
farther away. Maybe you're in
Connecticut, and you've got to drive into New York
City for these study groups.

But it is possible. It's possible to do it online. It's possible to find in-person
people as well to study with.

And I've heard students often
form a group that they then accompany-- they join, they
plan with across their studies.

If they're taking another
class, maybe they enroll in it with that same student. Sorry, Jon. I cut you off. JON NOTMAN: No, no, it's OK.

Yeah, just want to
reemphasize what you said. This is totally possible. We have more students that
are satisfied and set up

with study groups than not. But we provide you with a lot of
opportunities to network and mix

based on the course
you're enrolled in. So that shouldn't be
too much of a challenge, but I understand in
the past, some people

have brought that
up to our attention. OK. So with that being said, I'll
move on to the next segment.

And I want to take a
few minutes to talk about the Non-Degree program and
the part-time master's degree

program that Pax has
already kind of alluded to. So I want to go into
a little bit of detail and explain each program.

And if you have any questions
again, put them in the chat. So I'll talk about the
Non-Degree program. Stanford Engineering
specifically

designed this program to
provide working professionals such as yourselves
or anybody that's

completed their
undergraduate program and really don't have any
kind of in-depth experience

of a graduate-level program
or graduate-level courses. So this is the opportunity that
Stanford Engineering provides

for you to essentially
without committing to a long-term,
full-time program,

try out Stanford graduate
courses for credit, OK? And in some cases,
we have students

that are interested in
just a couple of courses to get obviously credit and
experience and the skills

and education from them. And then we also have
some students then who want to focus on
a subset of courses

in a certain area
that will potentially lead to a certificate. And that's what we call a
graduate certificate program.

But let me just talk a little
bit about applying, OK? We get a lot of questions
about applying and how it works

and a lot of concerns about
how much time it takes to apply and whether they'll
be accepted or not.

So again, the Non-Degree
program is nonmatriculated. It's not a full-time
degree program.

I consider this to be a
part-time Non-Degree program, OK? So that's the first definition
that we need to provide.

You can apply for the Non-Degree
program any academic quarter. You can apply during autumn,
winter, spring, or summer.

With the degree
program which I'll talk about in a few
minutes, that's different. There are only certain
times of year you can apply.

So you can actually start the
Non-Degree program any time you wish. It's a simple application, OK?

It's through our My
Stanford Connection portal that is created
by SCPD specifically.

And it is not the
same application as a master's degree. It is quite simple, quite easy. It doesn't take too
long to complete.

That application will require
you to complete segments, for example, a
statement of purpose,

provide transcripts, all the
documentation that we will need to see if you meet the
standard academic need

for the courses or program
that you're applying for. It's flexible. You do not need to
enroll every quarter.

Like, master's degree program
does require continuous study. This does not. You can take a course,
take a quarter off.

You can take two
courses, take a year off. That's entirely your choice. It's totally flexible. There's no commitment from
you to enroll every quarter,

I just want to say that. And that's what I'm mentioning
is noncontinuous enrollment. It's not flexible in
that this is self-paced.

As I mentioned
earlier on, you must-- if you're enrolling in
credit-bearing courses

with a Non-Degree program, you
must follow the academic quarter structure. It's typically 10 weeks long.

Some are slightly different. It's a little quicker
than 10 weeks. It's like between 8 and 9 weeks.

But having said that, it's
flexible in terms of you can enroll whatever you wish to
suit your kind of circumstance,

whether you're
working or whatever. One thing I do want to point
out is this is nonnegotiable.

For the Non-Degree
program, you must have an undergraduate degree. We do not accept applications
without an undergraduate degree.
If in some cases-- and I know I'm British, right? I'm European.

Back in the day, there was
the opportunity for students what we call to
be mature students and not undertake an
undergraduate degree

and go straight into a master's
degree or baccalaureate or whatever. That's fine. That obviously counts.

But if you don't have formal
education like a bachelor's of science degree or
anything like that, then the application
won't be accepted.

We have to have that
standard in place. I want to talk a little bit
about the graduate certificates

that we offer. Now these are different
from taking single courses for credit. These are a subset
of courses that you

can take in a certain
discipline that will then count towards a
credential, a certificate.

These are accredited
programs, but they are still in the category of Non-Degree.

As you take courses through a
graduate certificate program, there are typically required
courses on some electives,

depending on which
one you select. And you must maintain
a B or better.

You must maintain
an academic standard to continue through the
program and complete. So you are required to get a B
or better in all of the courses

that you take within a
graduate certificate. That's a must. For the graduate certificate,
you have up to three years

to complete. So if you're thinking, depending
on which graduate certificate you opt for-- it can be three
or four courses, typically--

you should be able to complete
that within three years. Again, you can
pause, take breaks. We understand things
happen with work and life,

but three years is a
pretty sufficient amount of time to complete it. And as we mentioned
earlier on, this

applies to both the
graduate certificate and taking individual
courses for credit. If you apply and are accepted
into a Stanford Engineering

master's program, you
have the opportunity to apply up to 18 units of
credit to the master's degree

if you are admitted, OK? The master's degree which
I'll talk about in a second

is typically 45 units, so
you're kind of almost halfway there, depending on what
courses you've taken

and what courses and credits
that the academic department will allow you to
apply to your degree.

OK, so moving on, I want to talk
a little bit about the Honors Coop Program, which is the
acronym, the HCP, which

is a part-time master's degree. I'll talk a little bit first
about the application process.

Now this is different
to Non-Degree. It's the same application as
the full-time degree program.

It is an extensive application. It is not quick. It's not simple. There's a lot of requirements
that you have to meet.

So the application for the
full-time master's degree is the same as the
full-time degree.

It's at the point where if
you're admitted to the program, you're accepted into the
program that at that point

you can elect. I want to take this in a
part-time capacity or no, I want to take this in
a full-time capacity.

So that's the difference. We get a lot of confusion about
whether the Honors Cooperative Program part-time master's
degree application is the same

or not as the full-time degree. It is the same. The application will be reviewed
through the academic department

that you're applying to. So, for example, if you're
interested in a Stanford computer science
master's degree,

you will be applying through
that specific department, and they will review
that application.

And again, if you meet the
requirements of the program and they're happy
with your application, they are the ones that will be
reviewing and approving that.

If you are interested in
a specific master's degree program, we would always
encourage-- we can provide you

with information. We can help you kind get
the basics of understanding the programs and how they work,

themselves have a lot of
information and a lot of detail and a lot of information about
deadlines and how to apply

and when to apply on
their department website. That's the place
you should really go to to get a lot of
extensive information.

We can provide you
with those links. We can send you
that information, but that's like
where you really want

to start in terms of
getting that profound amount of information so you
can understand exactly

the program that
you're applying to and hopefully will
be admitted to. I want to talk a little bit
about the degree program itself.

You will be considered a
fully matriculated student. You have the rights
and privileges of a full-time student.

You are no different, OK? And again, I want
to emphasize you are a fully matriculated student.

The difference is you would
be considered if you apply and elect part-time, you
would be a part-time student

where you can attend
classes, lectures, information sessions, office
hours in person or online.

That's your choice. So it's kind of hybrid, right? So you can come to
campus if you wish. Or if you want to be remote,
that's totally fine as well.

If you want to kind
of mix it up and do remote one quarter and in
person the next quarter, you can do that. That's your right
to do that, OK?

But you do have the ability
to study in person or online. That's entirely your choice.

One thing I want to make mention
about and I'm sure a lot of you will have questions
about this is that not all of the
master's degree programs

can be done remotely. We do have some that
can be done remotely, but by the nature of the
program, they cannot, OK?

The courses are just
not offered online, or some courses can't be really
completed and engaged online.

So there's a lot of
reasons for that, OK? And again, we can provide you
with information on what degrees

can be completed remotely
and which cannot. And again, that
department will have that information on their
degree program website.

And I just want to make
mention as well in all degrees, only some concentrations
are available online.

So, for example, if I
take computer science, they have concentrations,
specializations

that can be completed fully
online, some partially online, and some that just can't
be completed online. So you have to
kind of understand

which specialization or
concentration that you are interested in and then
understanding whether you would

be required to come to campus
for some of that degree or not, depending on what you select.

So that's kind of talking a
little bit about the degree program. And I guess we'll go
to the next slide.

OK. So I just want to talk
a little bit again. Just to kind of

You have to, for

or whatever the

That is a federal requirement. We are required to take your

can be a driver's license,

As I mentioned earlier on, there

program you're interested in and why you feel it will be

that course or program, so. You can write that, and you can

courses and want to refine it

based on your change of focus. Then you could do that. When you enroll-- so that's
the application process.

When you submit
your application, that would then be reviewed
by the academic department

to which course you are
applying for, whether it's computer science, electrical
engineering, or whatever. They will review the
application formally.

But again, I do want
to mention it's not as extensive as the degree
program application.

It is quite different. So to enroll in
courses, you must meet the course and department
prerequisite requirements.

That's again nonnegotiable. If you're required to have
linear algebra or Python in place, they want to see that.

They want to see that you've
completed a course with a grade or for credit to show
that you have the ability

to meet the requirements
to enter the course. Again, just want to
mention you can enroll

in any quarter courses offered. We try to offer as many
courses as we can during each of the academic quarters.

Winter, autumn,
and spring, we do offer an extensive
schedule of courses. Some are not so much.

It's a little bit less. But again, there
are some key courses that you can take during
the summer months.

You must, as I mentioned
earlier on, earn a B or better to keep taking courses. Particularly for the
graduate certificate,

it's important that
you get a B or better to continue through and
complete the program. If you just want to take
individual courses for credit

which is not via a graduate
certificate program, you do have to again keep a
standard of a B or better.

If you get less
than a B, you will need to petition to continue. That's not to say
you can't continue

but the academic department
will want to kind of understand why the grade wasn't as great
as it what should have been

and what you can do to
continue going forward. As I mentioned earlier
on, you can skip quarters.

You do not need to be
continually enrolled. And in some cases, students
will skip quarters again

based on work requirements,
or maybe the course that they need to take is not
offered that particular quarter

or whatever it might be. For the graduate certificate,
as I mentioned earlier on, you will take anywhere
between three to four courses

to earn a graduate certificate
in that concentration area. We get a lot of questions
about, well, I've

completed the requirements
of the certificate, completed the four courses, but I
want to take the others. Yeah, it's totally fine.

You don't have to stop
after three or four courses. You want to continue and
take the rest of the courses in the graduate certificate.

You're totally OK to do that. As I mentioned earlier
on, up to three years to complete the
graduate certificate.

And you will earn a
Stanford transcript. You will get an official
Stanford University transcript

which lists the
courses you completed, when you completed them, the
grade and the number of credits, as well as, most

It will have your Stanford
GPA on that transcript. And you have the
opportunity to request that

complete the courses

and you get a B or better or
above in any of the courses then, you will get an accredited
Non-Degree graduate certificate

from Stanford University. That will be provided to you
on completion of the program.
